fields.title: Computer Ethics
fields.content:
Computer Ethics

<hr data-start="303" data-end="306" class="">

What is Computer Ethics?

Computer ethics refers to the set of rules and principles that guide how we use computers and technology in a responsible and respectful way.

It helps us understand the difference between right and wrong when using computers, the internet, or any digital device.

Why is Computer Ethics Important?

  1. To respect others online

  2. To prevent cyberbullying and crime

  3. To use the internet safely

  4. To protect our personal information

  5. To become responsible digital citizens

Examples of Good Computer Ethics

  1. Respecting people's privacy

    • Do not read other people’s emails or messages without permission.

  2. Not stealing or copying software (piracy)

    • Use only legal software. Do not download cracked or pirated programs.

  3. Avoiding plagiarism

    • Do not copy other people's work and claim it as your own. Always give credit.

  4. Not spreading false information

    • Share only what is true and verified. Avoid spreading fake news.

  5. Being kind and respectful online

    • Do not send rude or harmful messages. Treat people online the same way you treat them face-to-face.

Examples of Bad Computer Ethics

  1. Hacking into someone’s account or computer

  2. Spreading computer viruses

  3. Sharing personal or sensitive information without permission

  4. Using computers to cheat in exams or assignments

  5. Bullying others on social media (cyberbullying)

<hr data-start="1827" data-end="1830" class="">

Basic Rules of Computer Ethics

These are sometimes called the Ten Commandments of Computer Ethics. Here are a few simplified ones:

  1. Do not use a computer to harm other people.

  2. Do not use a computer to steal.

  3. Do not use other people’s computer files without permission.

  4. Do not copy or use software without paying for it.

  5. Use computers in ways that show respect and honesty.

Tips for Being a Good Digital Citizen

  • Always log out after using a public computer.

  • Do not open unknown email attachments.

  • Keep your password safe – do not share it with friends.

  • Report any bad behavior or online danger to an adult or teacher.

  • Think before you post anything online.

Conclusion

Computer ethics helps us use technology in a smart, safe, and respectful way. As students, it is important to always follow these rules and be good digital citizens.
fields.summary: Computer ethics helps us use technology in a smart, safe, and respectful way. As students, it is important to always follow these rules and be good digital citizens.

fields.title: Database Management
fields.content:
Database Management

<hr>

1. Introduction to Database Management

What is a Database?

A database is an organized collection of related data that can be easily accessed, managed, and updated. It is used to store information in a structured way for quick retrieval and manipulation.

Example: A school may have a database that stores student records, including names, ages, grades, and addresses.

<hr>

What is Database Management?

Database Management refers to the use of software to create, store, retrieve, update, and delete data in a database system efficiently.

<hr>

2. Database Management System (DBMS)

Definition

A Database Management System (DBMS) is software that helps users to interact with the database. It manages data, the database engine, and the database schema to facilitate data organization and manipulation.

Examples of DBMS software:

  • Microsoft Access

  • MySQL

  • Oracle

  • SQLite

  • PostgreSQL

<hr>

Functions of a DBMS

  1. Data storage, retrieval, and update

  2. User access control

  3. Data security and integrity

  4. Backup and recovery

  5. Data independence

  6. Concurrency control (multiple users at once)

<hr>

3. Types of Databases

a. Flat File Database

  • A single table stored as a plain text or spreadsheet file.

  • Simple and suitable for small tasks.

  • Example: CSV file of student marks.

b. Relational Database

  • Stores data in tables (relations).

  • Uses primary keys and foreign keys to connect tables.

  • Most common type used today.

  • Example: MySQL, Oracle.

c. Hierarchical Database

  • Organizes data in a tree-like structure.

  • Parent-child relationships.

  • Example: Early IBM systems.

d. Network Database

  • Similar to hierarchical but allows more complex relationships (many-to-many).

  • Data can have multiple parent and child records.

e. Object-Oriented Database

  • Stores data as objects (like in object-oriented programming).

  • Better suited for complex data and multimedia.

<hr>

4. Components of a Database System

  1. Hardware: Physical devices (servers, storage systems).

  2. Software: DBMS and related applications.

  3. Data: Raw facts stored in the database.

  4. Users:

    • Database administrators (DBAs)

    • Application programmers

    • End users

  5. Procedures: Rules and instructions for designing and using the database.

<hr>

5. Database Models

  • Relational Model: Data organized in rows and columns.

  • Hierarchical Model: Tree-like structure.

  • Network Model: Graph-like structure.

  • Object-Oriented Model: Stores complex data as objects.

<hr>

6. Database Terminologies

<th>Term</th> <th>Meaning</th>
Table A collection of related data arranged in rows and columns
Record (Row) A single data item in a table
Field (Column) A specific piece of information within a record
Primary Key A unique identifier for each record in a table
Foreign Key A field that links two tables
Query A request to access or modify data in the database
Form A user-friendly interface to input data into the database
Report A formatted printout of data for analysis
<hr>

7. Database Operations (CRUD)

<th>Operation</th> <th>Meaning</th> <th>Example</th>
C - Create Add new data Add a new student record
R - Read Retrieve/view data Search for student grades
U - Update Modify existing data Change a student’s address
D - Delete Remove data Delete a student who graduated
<hr>

8. Advantages of Database Management Systems

  • Reduces data redundancy

  • Ensures data integrity and accuracy

  • Improves data security

  • Easier data sharing among users

  • Supports multiple users at once

  • Better backup and recovery features

  • Centralized control over data

<hr>

9. Disadvantages of DBMS

  • Can be expensive to set up

  • Requires trained personnel

  • System failure may affect all users

  • Complexity in design and maintenance

<hr>

10. SQL – Structured Query Language

SQL is the standard language used to interact with a relational database.

Common SQL Commands

<pre>-- Creating a table CREATE TABLE Students ( ID INT PRIMARY KEY, Name VARCHAR(50), Age INT, Class VARCHAR(10) ); -- Inserting data INSERT INTO Students (ID, Name, Age, Class) VALUES (1, 'Ama Boateng', 16, 'SHS 2'); -- Selecting data SELECT * FROM Students; -- Updating data UPDATE Students SET Age = 17 WHERE ID = 1; -- Deleting data DELETE FROM Students WHERE ID = 1; </pre><hr>

11. Roles of a Database Administrator (DBA)

  • Designing and maintaining the database structure

  • Ensuring data security

  • Creating user accounts and permissions

  • Backing up and restoring data

  • Monitoring performance and making improvements

<hr>

12. Real-life Applications of Databases

  • Schools: Student records, grades, attendance

  • Banks: Customer accounts, transactions

  • Hospitals: Patient information, treatment history

  • Online stores: Inventory, orders, customer data

  • Social media: User profiles, posts, messages

<hr>

Conclusion

Database management is essential in today’s digital world. It helps organizations and individuals manage vast amounts of data efficiently and securely. SHS students must understand how databases work and how to use them responsibly.
fields.summary: Database management is essential in today’s digital world. It helps organizations and individuals manage vast amounts of data efficiently and securely. SHS students must understand how databases work and how to use them responsibly.

fields.title: Database Management
fields.summary: Databases are essential tools in today’s digital world. They allow us to store and retrieve large amounts of information efficiently. Structured databases, like those built in PostgreSQL, are organized and powerful, ideal for school records, banking systems, and businesses. On the other hand, unstructured databases handle things like multimedia, documents, and social media data.
